title: 114_s2241
content: The Act titled "Combat Heroin Epidemic and Backlog Act of 2015" amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to address the use of heroin and associated drugs by granting authority to address public safety and heroin distribution, sale, and use. The Act aims to assist States and Indian tribes in addressing the distribution, sale, and use of heroin, fentanyl, and associated synthetic drugs through grant programs authorized by the Attorney General. Grants can be used for various projects to enhance public safety and address backlogs in forensic science laboratories. The Act authorizes grant programs to assist laboratories in addressing backlogs of untested samples of heroin, fentanyl, and synthetic drugs, reimburse for equipment procurement to improve efficiency, support law enforcement agencies with field-testing equipment, and aid in investigating and prosecuting individuals violating drug laws. The Act authorizes grant programs to assist laboratories in addressing backlogs of untested samples of heroin, fentanyl, and synthetic drugs, reimburse for equipment procurement to improve efficiency, support law enforcement agencies with field-testing equipment, and aid in investigating and prosecuting individuals violating drug laws. Funding of $10,000,000 for each fiscal year 2017, 2018, and 2019 is authorized for State, tribal, and local health department services to address the use of heroin, fentanyl, and associated synthetic drugs. The Act authorizes grant programs to assist laboratories in addressing backlogs of untested samples of heroin, fentanyl, and synthetic drugs. Funding is allocated based on the population of each State, with 25% at the Attorney General's discretion for competitive awards. Considerations for awards include the average annual number of violent crimes reported by each State. The Act authorizes grant programs to assist laboratories in addressing backlogs of untested samples of heroin, fentanyl, and synthetic drugs. Funding is allocated based on the population of each State, with a minimum requirement for each State to receive 0.6 percent of the total amount available. American Samoa and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands are considered as 1 State for allocation purposes. Funding is allocated based on the population of each State, with 67 percent going to American Samoa and 33 percent to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands.
